job_title: Patient Access Representative in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Great pto benefits and my bosses have always been very flexible with me
cons: No healthcare coverage for employees

job_title: Sponsored Projects Officer in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The work became very monotonous, but the pay was decent. The best benefit is free higher education, and free education for your dependents.
cons: But it's a state job, so getting a raise is quite difficult, and when you do get one, it doesn't matter because the cost of health care benefits has gone up so much.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in UNM, NM
pros: Excellent Health Care Plans, Collaborative Research, Flexible hours
cons: Soft money, contracts renewed yearly based on grant funding. Little growth opportunities

review_title: Great place to collaborate and investigate exciting science.
job_title: Associate Scientist II in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Collaborative environment Cost of living Highest per capita grant funds for school size Mountains right next door to the east, hot springs directly north.
cons: Albuquerque can be a dangerous place, so lock your doors at all times.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Albuquerque, NM
pros: This job is great for patient contact experiences and research.
cons: The pay is not too much.

pros: Diverse work environment, busy hospital
cons: Very high workload. Significant staff shortages.

job_title: Education Support Coordinator in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Location, education credit, flexible schedule.
cons: Unavailability to move up in your field Pay cap

job_title: Part-time Student Employee in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great way to make money while in college. Most departments will work around your school schedule. Don't need to work during Winter Break when University is closed.
cons: Capped at 28 hours a week, but they occasionally let you work more during school breaks. No benefits, no leave balances, no insurance, no paid time off during Winter Break.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Lots of different specialties and entities you can go into
cons: Most management sucks and pay is not fair and theres no way to ask for a raise at all.

pros:
Tuition remission benefits

Additional paid time off during the Christmas/New Year holidays (winter break)

Great annual leave accural 

salaries of most employees are public information

 some departments are great to work in (highly dependent on who is your manager)
cons:
Simple processes are unnecessary slow (it takes UNM to process checks 20 days after an invoice is submitted and they have a history of being late on payments)

It's notoriously difficult to fire a bad employee (and sometimes they also get raises because they're friends with the right people) 

Salaries are low and not competitive compared to other employers 

Yearly salary increases are unheard of. 

No bonuses

Hard to get promotions and/or merit salary increases (unless you know the right people, which shouldn't even be a factor). 

You have to pay for parking ($300-500/year at some parking lots, but higher ups who can actually afford it end up parking for free). 

So, so many levels of approvals and redtape, which stifles innovative ideas

review_title: UNM HSC is  a great place to work
pros: I have been vey successful working as a scientist on models of human disease as well as basic reserch. The environment is great and so are the benefits
cons: One needs to make extra effort to communicate with and collaborate with researches outside UNM HSC

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Good sense of community
Excellent research opportunities in biomedical sciences
cons:
Poor salary
High crime level on campus

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros:
Friendly co-workers
Good food in the hospital cafeteria
cons:
Salary is on the low side
UNM Hospital is not clean

pros: Paid time off, paid holidays
cons: Asked to perform multiple jobs

pros: Great coworkers, remote options, and a lot of support.
cons: Large organization with allot of moving parts. Individual achievements easy to be overlooked.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor (Non-Tenure) in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Salary will be dependent on department and PI.
cons: Salary is low and does not match job responsibilities.

job_title: Operations Specialist in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Working with faculty and students
cons: Low overall salaries, too much crime in the main campus area.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Cutting edge medical research and education
cons: poor pay and compensation for graduate workers. Long work hours.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great team, rewarding, Busy, pay
cons: Fulfillment ,long hours, rollover , busy

pros: Great research opportunities and a very supportive mentorship structure.
cons: Administration can be slow to respond on some issues.

pros: Work with great staff who enjoy working with cancer patients. Good benefits. Great educational opportunities. Nice incentive opportunities. We treat patients from all walk of lives.
cons: Parking is a hassel. Pay may be a bit lower than other facilities in town. Everything must be approved through the state, so it takes forever to see change.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: There are occasional free coffees.
cons: Toxic work environment due to lack of appreciation for students. People who have only committed one offense, who are obviously not fit to work with students, still hold positions of power.

pros: Very relaxed environment, great coworkers, good benefits.
cons: Pay could be higher, but is balanced out with free tuition etc.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in UNM, NM
pros: Great mentors, opportunities, and research topics.
cons: Current construction is a nightmare.

pros: Great benefits. I accumulate annual leave like it's candy. I can almost take a three day weekend every other weekend with how fast leave accumulates. Also get PTO for a week and a half over Christmas and New Years and all other state holidays. Great co-workers. The senior leadership team at the CDD is fantastic. A great group of people at the CDD (for the most part). The only problems with working here are the rules implemented by UNM Pediatrics.
cons: If you work for the Pediatrics dept. their goal is to pay you the least amount of money possible. Also, they've been on an eight year pay freeze so there are no raises given. If you are trying to get promoted within you don't fare well on the equity grid if you are going up in grades. For example, a grade 7 applying for a grade 11 job will only have their experience counted at 50%. You are better off applying from outside of UNM. I work at the Center for Development and Disability which is all soft money funded but still the meddling of Pediatrics has caused us to loose out on hires because of they are trying to pay people as little as possible. The hiring process takes a laughably long time do to all the bureaucratic red tape, it's a miracle we get new hires at all.

pros: Benefits eligible position, and some are provided by UNM
cons: Postdocs not considered full employees, benefit eligible but not paid by UNM

job_title: Research Associate Professor in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Good health and other benefits
cons: Low pay and slow promotion

job_title: Allied Health Program Faculty in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Can't beat the college environment the learning and the variety of work assignments. As faculty I have quite a bit of flexibility in my schedule. I can champion projects that interest me and skip those that don't. The benefits package is extremely generous.
cons: Very difficult to establish a career ladder without an MD or PhD degree, this is a very MD centric environment akin to a club. If you are not in the club, you have no career ladder. The lack of career ladder leaves even senior employees feeling as if they are not valued. This in turn leads to employees seeking other opportunities. Finally, faculty salaries for those not on. The senior leadership/executive leadership club, are set at 25% percentile of industry standards. I have been with UNM for 12 years. Today is my last lecture....I am sad to be leaving and wish UNM was more invested in me. If I hadv12 years at another employer, I feel I would have significantly greater possibilities for advancement.

pros: UNMHSC offers a great balance between work and personal life. While some projects can be large, there's enough staff support to get it done. People are always given recognition when accomplishing a large task that will have a great affect on the department. Also, being part of UNM provides tuition remission which can go a long way to develop ones career (depending on supervisor of course).
cons: Not personally affected by this, but there seemed to be some drama with upper management. Also, the handling of some management issues took a long time through human resources. While career development far exceeds ones expectations, the ability to move up the career ladder seems limited. This may be due to the hiring and pay freezes, but as an IT person, there doesn't seem to be much room to move unless someone retires or leaves.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Albuquerque, NM
pros: You have the opportunity to learn a lot and get involved in various presentations and projects. They are good at making you feel appreciated through events, socials, free food galore, and a good sense of community. You accrue time QUICKLY and they are very generous in the vacation days given. Including 2 weeks additional during the holidays in December/January.
cons: The pay is horrific. Everyone is underpaid, they try to make up for it with good benefits and employee appreciation, but at the end of the day those things don't pay the bills.

review_title: Good Place to Work Depending on Department
pros: Excellent benefits, and liberal personal time policies.  Some departments are a joy to work for, while others seems to consistently have low morale.  It all depends on where you work within the university.
cons: Pay is quite a bit less than the standard.  Use outdated and inflexible systems.  Frequently the pawn in state political battles.  Skilled employees rarely stick around for long, as they can make a much better living elsewhere.

review_title: Good benefits, average pay, typical hospital politics
pros: Having four days off a week, health insurance was free (family coverage costs over 200$/mo. though), facility was up to date and clean.
cons: As a nurse working in a hospital, dealing with "hospital politics" is inevitable. There is and always will be favorites by upper management, and treatment of staff as either a "good" or "bad" employee will largely depend on who can brown their nose the darkest. Gossip, back biting, and passive aggressive jabs at people that are disfavored? You bet!

review_title: Working as a Nurse Aide for Staffing Office
pros: Ms. Quintana was the absolute best Supervisor I'll ever have. She granted me the opportunity to come onto her team. All the other supervisors were lovely staff that worked well with my sickly days. I loved the job. I loved the pay, especially for the part time.
cons: Like all other jobs, it's crucial that you show up to your assignment for the day in a timely manner. This job is not for you if you cannot be professional, courteous, and respectful of other peoples beliefs. You may sometimes get called off work on the morning of your assignment.

review_title: Micromanagement, favoritism and widespread low morale
pros:
Benefits (were great, now just good or above average)
Tuition remission
Laudermill law protection after trial period (vs "at-will" employment
University atmosphere
Faculty & Staff club
Generous leave (vacation, sick, catastrophic leave & paid holidays)
Management training via Human Resources
cons:
Unqualified managers/Department Chairs and administrators
Micromanagement
Favoritism and cronyism among staff as well as faculty
Near permanent freeze on raises & promotions in most departments
Cutbacks in staff have left remaining staff overworked and underpaid

review_title: I was doing the work of 4 people!
job_title: Medical Residency Coordinator in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Tuition and Health Coverage. Working around educated people or people being educated was nice.
cons: Red tape. Doing things in a non-progressive way. Lazy people. Low pay. Terrible parking (had to park a mile away). Gossipy workplace. Low morale. Unmotivated & irrational coworkers. People who don't take pride in their work. Corrupt systems. Non-productive processes. Bad management. The list goes on......

pros: Good benefits and time off. Great opportunity to get started in the professional world. Faculty helped with adapting to 'real world' from a medicolegal standpoint in practice.
cons: Faculty sometimes would intimidate, undermine and put residents against each other. Fabricate stories about personal lives of residents. Emphasis to use Surgery center was not always patient centered and counter productive to educational achievement.

pros: It was better than no job at all.
cons: Overall, UNM has a serious culture problem. It is a bloated bureaucracy, heavily political, and everyone has an agenda. Faculty are valued much more than staff. Budget cuts rule the atmosphere, but somehow faculty members always manage to get raises, bonuses, and awards, even though many of them are lazy, rude, and unwilling to be team players. All four of my siblings attended UNM, while my undergraduate degree was from NMSU. I always thought UNM was great until I worked there. I have nothing good to say about this place. They should just shut it down.

review_title: Great place to be for the location, needs to focus on management training and morale.
pros: Benefits, steady employment, large employer of the city.
cons: Management needs training to focus on morale and overall institutional mission.

pros:
After working at several other hospitals, I think this is actually a pretty good one. For the most part they provide quality care. I did not feel this way when I worked there. 
The cafeteria is also very good for hospital food. The green chili on everything helps.
cons: Cockroaches in the hospital, including what should be sterile areas.

job_title: Director Emerging Learning Strategies in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Very dedicated faculty and staff who are interested in innovative educational methodology.  Faculty and staff are extremely involved with, and dedicated to the students.  Faculty are creative with their pedagogy.
cons: Top heavy.  Decisions are often made by those who do not teach or know the students.

job_title: Patient Services Representative in Albuquerque, NM
pros: good doctors and nurses, for the most part its a good job, you have to deal with a lot of bad management.
cons: bad management in patient services.  A lot of turnover. Unfriendly and hateful patient services management.  They always say if you don't like your job there is the door.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Office of research supports basic research.
Multidisciplinary science labs
cons:
Benefits are almost non-existing.
Post-doctoral fellows do not qualify for tuition remission, this limits training opportunities.
UNM does not follow the NIH recommended Post-doc payscale.
Most departments will not hire internally, including promoting post-docs

review_title: Treated like an entry level file clerk
pros: Good pay. Subsidized cafeteria.  Okay hours
cons: I was treated like a child.  Job was just phones and files. Parking close to work was so expensive I had to park in never never land. NEVER AGAIN.

review_title: Great place to work, and grow as a professional.
pros: Excellent teaching/mentoring programs. A great place to grow in your career with many opportunities.
cons: Upper management not sensitive to the growing exposure of RNs to traumatic situations. Follow up would be proactive and helpful.

pros: My boss is very open to feedback and grants me a high degree of autonomy.
cons: I had to be present at too many meetings that the majority of the material was not directly related to me.

pros: Everything except the pay.  This is a fairly under-served patient population as well.
cons: Salary stays the same, years after starting employment with them.

job_title: IRACDA-ASERT Postdoctoral Fellow in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The ASERT program is amazing. Provides many opportunities to learn and practice science education. Many education workshops offered via OMED. The people are generally very nice.
cons: Not much unity between or within departments. Feels rather isolated.

pros: good benefits  with  good pay  everyday patient interaction
cons: no opportunity  to advance in  the hospital

job_title: Technical Support Analyst II in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great organization, great people, great benefits!
cons: UNM salary compensation is below market for IT in Albuquerque area.

pros: Insurance, work environment and salary
cons: I worked there as student part time. So, i don't know if its different for other people. No/min sick leaves

review_title: As a research postdoc: Good coworkers, good facilities, mediocre pay
pros: Good coworkers, good research equipment, flexible schedule
cons: Lower than average postdoc pay

review_title: it is very nice experience to work here
pros: life cost is not high and interesting city culture
cons: too far to any where else

review_title: Awesome boss with high technical knowledge

pros: Time flexible, nice workspace and ample time to learn things
cons: irregular personal funds may lay off.

pros: Benefits, work hours, autonomy, flexibility, time off

pay, lack of training
difficulty navigating EMR--not the easiest one to use

pros: many opportunities for professional growth

pros: benefits, diversity, academics, PC, environment

pros: Great colleagues and good work life balance
